heroTag: I bring human simplicity into complex AI systems.
about:
Hey! I'm Bharath Vishal - welcome to my little corner of the internet.
This site is basically a mix of everything I do and learn - a blend of my career in AI product management, my experiments in data and design, and the random thoughts that spill out of my head when I'm trying to make sense of how tech actually feels human.

I've spent the past few years moving between analytics, automation, and product roles - figuring out how to connect the dots between data, users, and business. Somewhere along the way, I realized I love that intersection - where logic meets creativity.

So here you'll find my projects, blogs, and sometimes even half-baked ideas that explore how AI can make products more human (and maybe a little smarter).

Think of this site as part blog, part resume, part digital whiteboard - and 100% me trying to build, learn, and share as I go.

blogs.title: How Steve Jobs's Personal Trauma Shaped the iPhone in Your Hand
blogs.subheading: Not all ideas come up from apple falling from tree, some can be result of years of personal issues.
blogs.content:
Steve Jobs: The Man Who Connected His Dots

Every big personality has a story, and Steve Jobs was no different. He was like a complicated tapestry - full of bright threads and dark patches. To understand his famous Apple products, we must look at his life and see how his personal dots connected.

The Deep Pain of Being Given Away

Steve was born in 1955 and adopted by a simple, loving couple, Paul and Clara Jobs. But the feeling of being given away always sat heavy in his heart. This pain made him an intense person, finding it hard to trust people completely.

This lack of trust turned into a need for control in his work. He didn't want Apple products to depend on anyone else. This is why Apple built a self-contained world - they control the hardware, the software, and even the store. His fear of being let down became his strength: it made the product flawless, complete, and unique.

The Calligraphy Lesson and Father's Wisdom

Even though he dropped out of Reed College, Steve sneaked into a calligraphy class. He simply loved the beauty of the letters and the way space was handled. It was just a hobby, but ten years later, this is why the Macintosh was the first computer with beautiful, multiple fonts. He brought art to the machine.

His father, Paul Jobs, gave him a great lesson: "Paint even the back of the fence, the part no one sees." For Steve, this meant that quality is not just for show; it is about integrity. He made sure the circuit boards inside the computer were laid out perfectly, even though the user would never look inside.

The India Trip: Finding Peace in Simplicity

In 1974, young Steve traveled to India looking for a guru and some spiritual peace. He was disappointed he couldn't meet his guru, but the journey still changed his life.

He saw people in ashrams and villages living happily with very few possessions. He realised that "Simplicity is the highest form of sophistication."

This spiritual learning became the core of Apple's design. The iPod had one button, the iPhone had one home screen, and the products focused only on what was essential. He learned to remove clutter, believing that less is always more.

The Humble Washing Machine Story

Steve's obsession with design and quality wasn't only for computers; it was for everything in his life. When he and his wife, Laurene, were setting up their home, they needed a washing machine.

Most people buy a washing machine quickly, but Steve spent weeks researching. He wanted to understand the deepest purpose of the machine. He compared water usage, energy, and how gently it treated the clothes.

He finally chose a Miele machine because he felt it matched his values: clean, efficient, and quiet. This small story shows his mind was always on design. He looked at every object - from a phone to a washing machine - with deep thought and an urge to make it better and purer.

Control Turns Against Him

Steve believed deeply in purity - in mind, body, and work. This led him to follow very strict fruit diets, which he thought kept his system clean and sharp.

But this need for purity became dangerous. When he was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2003, he tried to cure himself with only diet and alternative medicine for nine months, refusing surgery. By the time he agreed to the operation, it was tragically late. His greatest strength - control - was the thing that ultimately went against him.

Connecting the Dots

In the end, Steve Jobs didn't just build machines; he poured his soul and his life lessons into them. As he said, "You can't connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backward."

His products are a beautiful connection of all his life's dots: the simplicity from India, the perfection from his father, and the beauty from calligraphy. He taught the world that a computer, a phone, or even a simple piece of technology can and should be a work of art.
